page.title: 04Farming
page.content: Whilst there are a few fields used for grazing a large proportion is rough moorland used by "Commoners' Rights" mainly for sheep but with a few cattle and ponies. Many of the dry stone walls have been allowed to fall into disrepair and grazing land has reverted to rough land encroached by bracken. Most former farmsteads have become small-holdings, the majority of the associated land sold to farmers whose farms are up to 10 miles distant. Sheep grazing has an adverse effect on the natural moorland due to the close cropping of grasses. The black-faced and Cheviot are hardy breeds, as are the Galloway black cattle, being able to surive severe weather except for very deep snow.
